source_paper.title: Benchmark dataset and deep learning method for global tropical cyclone forecasting

ml_task.problem_statement: Predicting tropical cyclone track and intensity over time using historical meteorological data.
ml_task.input_description: 42 hours of historical tropical cyclone data including: 1D inherent attributes (longitude, latitude, pressure, wind), 3D meteorological grid data (geopotential height, specific humidity, temperature, U/V wind at multiple pressure levels), and environment data (month, movement velocity, historical moving direction, subtropical high region). Input sequence length n=8 time steps.
ml_task.output_description: 24-hour forecast of tropical cyclone track (longitude, latitude) and intensity (maximum wind speed, minimum central pressure). Output sequence length m=4 time steps.

secondary_metrics: Performance on rapid track change cases
evaluation_criteria.reported_performance: TCNM outperforms both existing deep learning methods and official meteorological forecasts across multiple metrics, achieving the highest prediction accuracy among the deep learning methods tested.

data_details.format: Multimodal dataset with heterogeneous meteorological data
data_details.structure_description: Dataset divided into three parts: inherent attribute data (1D time series), meteorological grid data (3D spatial-temporal data), and environment data (contextual features). Contains 3630 tropical cyclones across six ocean basins with 70 years of multi-source data.
data_details.target_column_or_logic: Targets are future track positions (longitude, latitude) and intensity measurements (maximum wind speed, minimum central pressure) for the next 24 hours.

model_details.architecture_family: Deep Learning Model with Meteorology Integration
